title: Authors and Citation
text: Reetam Majumder. Author, maintainer. Steven Xu. Author. Brian Reich. Contributor.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Majumder R, Xu S (2026). SPQR: Semi-Parametric Quantile Regression. R package version 0.5.0, https://reetamm.github.io/SPQR/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {SPQR: Semi-Parametric Quantile Regression},   author = {Reetam Majumder and Steven Xu},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.5.0},   url = {https://reetamm.github.io/SPQR/}, }

title: Semi-Parametric Quantile Regression
text: SPQR R package implements semi-parametric quantile regression (SPQR) method Xu Reich (2021) [1]. allows flexible modeling conditional distribution function quantile function. package provides three estimation procedures: maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) maximum posteriori (MAP) point estimates computationally lighter, Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) fully Bayesian computationally heavier. MLE MAP estimates obtained using Adam routine torch, whereas MCMC estimate obtained using Stan-like Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC) -U-turn sampler (NUTS).

title: Semi-Parametric Quantile Regression
text: can install development version SPQR GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("reetamm/SPQR")

title: Semi-Parametric Quantile Regression
text: Estimate normal mixture distribution:
code: library(SPQR) set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5) Y <- rnorm(n, X, 0.8) control <- list(iter = 300, warmup = 200, thin = 1) fit <- SPQR(X = X, Y = Y, method = "MCMC", control = control, normalize = TRUE, verbose = FALSE)  ## summarize output print(fit, showModel = TRUE) #>  #> SPQR fitted using MCMC approach with ARD priorüöÄ #>  #> Model specification: #>     Layers #>    Input Output Activation #>        1     10       tanh #>       10     10    softmax #>  #> MCMC diagnostics: #>   Final acceptance ratio is 0.90 and target is 0.9 #>  #> Expected log pointwise predictive density (elpd) estimates: #>   elpd.LOO = 89.90853,  elpd.WAIC = 89.7359 #>  #> Elapsed time: 0.03 minutes  ## plot estimated PDF with 95% credible bands plotEstimator(fit, type = "PDF", X = 0, ci.level = 0.95)

title: Semi-Parametric Quantile Regression
text: [1] Xu, S.G. Reich, B.J., 2021. Bayesian nonparametric quantile process regression estimation marginal quantile effects. Biometrics.

title: quantile accumulated local effects (ALE) ‚Äî QALE
text: Computes quantile ALEs SPQR class object. function plots ALE main effects across tau using line plots single covariate, ALE interaction effects across tau using contour plots two covariates .

title: quantile accumulated local effects (ALE) ‚Äî QALE
code: QALE(   object,   var.index,   tau = seq(0.1, 0.9, 0.1),   n.bins = 40,   ci.level = 0,   getAll = FALSE,   pred.fun = NULL )

title: quantile accumulated local effects (ALE) ‚Äî QALE
text: object object class SPQR. var.index numeric scalar length-two vector indices covariates ALEs calculated. length(var.index) = 1, function computes main effect X[,var.index]. length(var.index) = 2, function computes interaction effect X[,var.index[1]] X[,var.index[2]]. tau quantiles interest. n.bins maximum number intervals covariate range divided   calculating ALEs. actual number intervals depends number unique values X[,var.index]. length(var.index) = 2, n.bins applied covariates. ci.level credible level computing pointwise credible intervals ALE length(var.index) = 1. default 0 indicating credible intervals computed. getAll TRUE length(var.index) = 1, extracts posterior samples ALE. pred.fun function used instead predict.SPQR() computing predicted quantiles given covariates. can useful user wants compare QALE calculated using SPQR using quantile regression models, maybe using true model simulation study.

title: quantile accumulated local effects (ALE) ‚Äî QALE
text: x length(var.index) = 1, (n.bins+1)-length vector specifying ordered predictor values ALE plot function calculated. break points n.bins intervals predictor range divided, plus lower boundary first interval upper boundary last interval. length(var.index) = 2, list two vectors, first containing X[,var.index[1]] values second containing X[,var.index[2]] values ALE plot function calculated. ALE length(var.index) = 1, (n.bins+1) length(tau) matrix predicted ALE values every combination x tau. length(var.index) = 2, 3-dimensional array predicted ALE values. slice corresponds quantile. Within slice, rows correspond X[,var.index[1]] columns correspond X[,var.index[2]].

title: quantile accumulated local effects (ALE) ‚Äî QALE
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- runif(n,0,2) Y <- rnorm(n,X^2,0.3+X/2) control <- list(iter = 200, warmup = 150, thin = 1) fit <- SPQR(X=X, Y=Y, n.knots=12, n.hidden=3, method="MCMC",             control=control, normalize=TRUE, verbose = FALSE)  ## compute quantile ALE main effect of X at tau = 0.2,0.5,0.8 ale <- QALE(fit, var.index=1, tau=c(0.2,0.5,0.8)) # }

title: Fitting SPQR models ‚Äî SPQR
text: Main function package. Fits SPQR using maximum likelihood estimation (MLE), maximum posterior (MAP) Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method. Returns object S3 class SPQR.

title: Fitting SPQR models ‚Äî SPQR
code: SPQR(   X,   Y,   n.knots = 10,   n.hidden = 10,   activation = c("tanh", "relu", "sigmoid"),   method = c("MLE", "MAP", "MCMC"),   prior = c("ARD", "GP", "GSM"),   hyperpar = list(),   control = list(),   normalize = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE,   seed = NULL,   ... )

title: Fitting SPQR models ‚Äî SPQR
text: X covariate matrix (without intercept column) Y response vector. n.knots number basis functions. Default: 10. n.hidden vector specifying number hidden neurons hidden layer. Default: 10. activation hidden layer activation. Either "tanh" (default) "relu". method Method estimating SPQR. One "MLE", "MAP" (default) "MCMC". prior prior model variance hyperparameters. One "GP", "ARD" (default) "GSM". hyperpar list named hyper-prior hyperparameters use instead default values, including a_lambda, b_lambda, a_sigma b_sigma. default value 0.001 four hyperparameters. control list named method-dependent parameters allows finer  control behavior computational approaches. 1. Parameters MLE MAP methods use.GPU TRUE GPU computing used torch::cuda_is_available() returns TRUE. Default: FALSE. lr learning rate used Adam optimizer, .e., torch::optim_adam(). dropout length two vector specifying dropout probabilities input hidden layers respectively. default c(0,0) indicating dropout. batchnorm TRUE batch normalization used hidden activation. epochs number passes entire training dataset gradient descent optimization. early.stopping.epochs used maximum number passes. Default: 200. batch.size size mini batches gradient calculation. Default: 128. valid.pct fraction data used validation set. Default: 0.2. early.stopping.epochs number epochs stopping validation loss decrease. Default: 10. print.every.epochs number epochs next training progress printed. Default: 10. save.path path save fitted torch model. default folder named "SPQR_model" created current working directory store model. save.name name file save fitted torch model. Default "SPQR.model.pt". 2. Parameters MCMC method parameters similar rstan::stan(). Detailed explanations can found Stan reference manual. algorithm sampling algorithm; "HMC": Hamiltonian Monte Carlo dual-averaging, "NUTS": -U-Turn sampler (default). iter number MCMC iterations (including warmup). Default: 2000. warmup number warm-/burn-iterations step-size mass matrix adaptation. Default: 500. thin number iterations saving next post-warmup samples. Default: 1. stepsize discretization interval/step-size \(\epsilon\) leap-frog integrator. Default NULL indicates adaptively selected warm-iterations. metric type mass matrix; "unit": diagonal matrix ones, "diag": diagonal matrix positive diagonal entries estimated warmup iterations (default), "dense": dense, symmetric positive definite matrix entries estimated warm-iterations. delta target Metropolis acceptance rate. Default: 0.9. max.treedepth maximum tree depth NUTS. Default: 6. int.time integration time HMC. number leap-frog steps calculated \(L_{\epsilon}=\lfloor t/\epsilon\rfloor\). Default: 0.3. normalize TRUE, covariates normalized take values [0,1]. verbose TRUE (default), training progress printed. seed Random number generation seed. ... parameters pass control.

title: Fitting SPQR models ‚Äî SPQR
text: object class SPQR. list containing mostly internal model fitting information used helper functions.

title: Fitting SPQR models ‚Äî SPQR
text: Xu SG, Reich BJ (2021). Bayesian Nonparametric Quantile Process Regression Estimation Marginal Quantile Effects. Biometrics. doi:10.1111/biom.13576

title: Fitting SPQR models ‚Äî SPQR
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5) Y <- rnorm(n, X, 0.8) control <- list(iter = 200, warmup = 150, thin = 1) fit <- SPQR(X = X, Y = Y, method = "MCMC", control = control,             normalize = TRUE, verbose = FALSE)  ## summarize output summary(fit) #>  #> SPQR fitted using MCMC approach with ARD priorüöÄ #>  #> MCMC diagnostics: #>   Final acceptance ratio is 0.95 and target is 0.9 #>  #> Expected log pointwise predictive density (elpd) estimates: #>   elpd.LOO = 90.10687,  elpd.WAIC = 89.59815 #>  #> Elapsed time: 0.02 minutes  ## plot estimated PDF plotEstimator(fit, type = "PDF", X = 0)  # }

what: autoplot method for class SPQR ‚Äî autoplot.SPQR
title: autoplot method for class SPQR ‚Äî autoplot.SPQR
text: function calls one following functions: plotEstimator(), plotGOF(), plotMCMCtrace(), plotQALE(), plotQVI()

title: autoplot method for class SPQR ‚Äî autoplot.SPQR
code: # S3 method for class 'SPQR' autoplot(object, output = c("GOF", "estimator", "trace", "QALE", "QVI"), ...)

title: autoplot method for class SPQR ‚Äî autoplot.SPQR
text: object object class SPQR. output character indicating type plot returned. "GOF": goodness fit test comparing quantiles probability integral transform (PIT) uniform distribution. "estimator": visualization various estimates, including probability density function (PDF), cumulative density function (CDF) quantile function (QF). "trace": diagnostic trace plots SPQR fitted method = "MCMC". "QALE": quantile accumulative local effects (ALE) visualizing covariate effects predicted quantiles. "QVI": quantile variable importance comparison. ... arguments passed specific plot function, see plotEstimator(), plotGOF(), plotMCMCtrace(), plotQALE() plotQVI() required arguments.

title: autoplot method for class SPQR ‚Äî autoplot.SPQR
text: ggplot object

title: autoplot method for class SPQR ‚Äî autoplot.SPQR
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5) Y <- rnorm(n, X, 0.8) control <- list(iter = 200, warmup = 150, thin = 1) fit <- SPQR(X = X, Y = Y, method = "MCMC", control = control,             normalize = TRUE, verbose = FALSE)  ## Goodness-of-fit test autoplot(fit, output = "GOF")  # }

what: coef method for class SPQR ‚Äî coef.SPQR
title: coef method for class SPQR ‚Äî coef.SPQR
text: Computes estimated spline coefficients SPQR class object

title: coef method for class SPQR ‚Äî coef.SPQR
code: # S3 method for class 'SPQR' coef(object, X, ...)

title: coef method for class SPQR ‚Äî coef.SPQR
text: object object class SPQR. X covariate vector/matrix coefficient calculated. ... arguments.

title: coef method for class SPQR ‚Äî coef.SPQR
text: NROW(X) K matrix containing values estimated coefficient, K number basis functions.

title: coef method for class SPQR ‚Äî coef.SPQR
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5) Y <- rnorm(n, X, 0.8) control <- list(iter = 200, warmup = 150, thin = 1) fit <- SPQR(X = X, Y = Y, method = "MCMC", control = control,             normalize = TRUE, verbose = FALSE) coef(fit, X = 0) #>       Coefs #> X       theta[1]   theta[2]   theta[3] theta[4]  theta[5]  theta[6]   theta[7] #>   [1,] 0.0148705 0.01241067 0.08595322 0.356902 0.3471123 0.1392085 0.03044411 #>       Coefs #> X         theta[8]    theta[9]   theta[10] #>   [1,] 0.004286563 0.002801199 0.006010941 # }

title: generate cross-validation folds ‚Äî createFolds.SPQR
text: Helper function generate cross-validation folds can used cv.SPQR.

title: generate cross-validation folds ‚Äî createFolds.SPQR
code: createFolds.SPQR(Y, nfold, stratified = FALSE)

title: generate cross-validation folds ‚Äî createFolds.SPQR
text: Y response vector. nfold number cross-validation folds. stratified TRUE, stratified folds based quantiles Y generated.

title: generate cross-validation folds ‚Äî createFolds.SPQR
text: list size nfold containing indices observations fold.

title: generate cross-validation folds ‚Äî createFolds.SPQR
code: set.seed(919) n <- 1000 X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5) Y <- rnorm(n, X, 0.8) folds <- createFolds.SPQR(Y, nfold = 5)

title: cross-validation for SPQR estimator ‚Äî cv.SPQR
text: Fits SPQR using either MLE MAP method computes K-fold cross-validation error.

title: cross-validation for SPQR estimator ‚Äî cv.SPQR
code: cv.SPQR(   folds,   X,   Y,   n.knots = 10,   n.hidden = 10,   activation = c("tanh", "relu", "sigmoid"),   method = c("MLE", "MAP", "MCMC"),   prior = c("ARD", "GP", "GSM"),   hyperpar = list(),   control = list(),   normalize = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE,   seed = NULL,   ... )

title: cross-validation for SPQR estimator ‚Äî cv.SPQR
text: folds list CV folds, possibly generated createFolds.SPQR(). X covariate matrix (without intercept column) Y response vector. n.knots number basis functions. Default: 10. n.hidden vector specifying number hidden neurons hidden layer. Default: 10. activation hidden layer activation. Either "tanh" (default) "relu". method Method estimating SPQR. One "MLE", "MAP" (default) "MCMC". prior prior model variance hyperparameters. One "GP", "ARD" (default) "GSM". hyperpar list named hyper-prior hyperparameters use instead default values, including a_lambda, b_lambda, a_sigma b_sigma. default value 0.001 four hyperparameters. control list named method-dependent parameters allows finer  control behavior computational approaches. 1. Parameters MLE MAP methods use.GPU TRUE GPU computing used torch::cuda_is_available() returns TRUE. Default: FALSE. lr learning rate used Adam optimizer, .e., torch::optim_adam(). dropout length two vector specifying dropout probabilities input hidden layers respectively. default c(0,0) indicating dropout. batchnorm TRUE batch normalization used hidden activation. epochs number passes entire training dataset gradient descent optimization. early.stopping.epochs used maximum number passes. Default: 200. batch.size size mini batches gradient calculation. Default: 128. valid.pct fraction data used validation set. Default: 0.2. early.stopping.epochs number epochs stopping validation loss decrease. Default: 10. print.every.epochs number epochs next training progress printed. Default: 10. save.path path save fitted torch model. default folder named "SPQR_model" created current working directory store model. save.name name file save fitted torch model. Default "SPQR.model.pt". 2. Parameters MCMC method parameters similar rstan::stan(). Detailed explanations can found Stan reference manual. algorithm sampling algorithm; "HMC": Hamiltonian Monte Carlo dual-averaging, "NUTS": -U-Turn sampler (default). iter number MCMC iterations (including warmup). Default: 2000. warmup number warm-/burn-iterations step-size mass matrix adaptation. Default: 500. thin number iterations saving next post-warmup samples. Default: 1. stepsize discretization interval/step-size \(\epsilon\) leap-frog integrator. Default NULL indicates adaptively selected warm-iterations. metric type mass matrix; "unit": diagonal matrix ones, "diag": diagonal matrix positive diagonal entries estimated warmup iterations (default), "dense": dense, symmetric positive definite matrix entries estimated warm-iterations. delta target Metropolis acceptance rate. Default: 0.9. max.treedepth maximum tree depth NUTS. Default: 6. int.time integration time HMC. number leap-frog steps calculated \(L_{\epsilon}=\lfloor t/\epsilon\rfloor\). Default: 0.3. normalize TRUE, covariates normalized take values [0,1]. verbose TRUE (default), training progress printed. seed Random number generation seed. ... parameters pass control.

title: cross-validation for SPQR estimator ‚Äî cv.SPQR
text: control list control parameters. cve cross-validation error. folds CV folds.

title: cross-validation for SPQR estimator ‚Äî cv.SPQR
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5) Y <- rnorm(n, X, 0.8) folds <- createFolds.SPQR(Y, nfold = 5) ## compute 5-fold CV error # cv.out <- cv.SPQR(folds=folds, X=X, Y=Y, method="MLE", #                   normalize = TRUE, verbose = FALSE) # }

title: load saved SPQR model ‚Äî load.SPQR
text: Load saved SPQR model designated path. function first loads .SPQR file stores SPQR object. checks whether SPQR model fitted method = "MCMC". , also loads .pt file storing torch model name attach SPQR object.

title: load saved SPQR model ‚Äî load.SPQR
code: load.SPQR(name = stop("`name` must be specified"), path = NULL)

title: load saved SPQR model ‚Äî load.SPQR
text: name name saved object excluding extension. path path look saved object. Default current working directory.

title: load saved SPQR model ‚Äî load.SPQR
text: object class SPQR.

title: load saved SPQR model ‚Äî load.SPQR
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5) Y <- rnorm(n, X, 0.8) fit <- SPQR(X = X, Y = Y, method = "MCMC", normalize = TRUE, verbose = FALSE) # save.SPQR(fit, name = "mcmc_fit") # fit <- load.SPQR("mcmc_fit") # }

title: plot SPQR estimators ‚Äî plotEstimator
text: Computes plots estimated PDF/CDF/QF curves.

title: plot SPQR estimators ‚Äî plotEstimator
code: plotEstimator(object, X, ...)

title: plot SPQR estimators ‚Äî plotEstimator
text: object object class "SPQR" X row vector indicating covariate values conditional PDF/CDF/QF computed plotted. ... Arguments passed predict.SPQR nY integer number indicating length grid Y specified. Default: 101. type function predicted; "PDF": probability density function, "CDF": cumulative distribution function, "QF": quantile function (default). tau grid quantiles quantile function computed. Default: seq(0.1,0.9,0.1). ci.level credible level computing pointwise credible intervals. default 0 indicating credible intervals computed. getAll TRUE, extracts posterior samples prediction. Default: FALSE.

title: plot SPQR estimators ‚Äî plotEstimator
text: ggplot object.

title: plot SPQR estimators ‚Äî plotEstimator
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5) Y <- rnorm(n, X, 0.8) control <- list(iter = 200, warmup = 150, thin = 1) fit <- SPQR(X = X, Y = Y, method = "MCMC", control = control,             normalize = TRUE, verbose = FALSE)   ## plot estimated PDF plotEstimator(fit, type = "PDF", X = 0)  # }

what: goodness-of-fit test for SPQR estimator ‚Äî plotGOF
title: goodness-of-fit test for SPQR estimator ‚Äî plotGOF
text: Performs goodness--fit test estimated conditional probability density function (PDF) using probability inverse transformation method.

title: goodness-of-fit test for SPQR estimator ‚Äî plotGOF
code: plotGOF(object, getAll = FALSE)

title: goodness-of-fit test for SPQR estimator ‚Äî plotGOF
text: object object class SPQR. getAll TRUE SPQR fitted method = "MCMC", plots posterior samples Q-Q lines. Default: FALSE.

title: goodness-of-fit test for SPQR estimator ‚Äî plotGOF
text: ggplot object.

title: goodness-of-fit test for SPQR estimator ‚Äî plotGOF
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5) Y <- rnorm(n, X, 0.8) control <- list(iter = 200, warmup = 150, thin = 1) fit <- SPQR(X = X, Y = Y, method = "MCMC", control = control,             normalize = TRUE, verbose = FALSE)  ## Goodness-of-fit test plotGOF(fit)  # }

title: plot MCMC trace plots ‚Äî plotMCMCtrace
text: Show trace plot log-likelihood estimates, "SPQR" class object fitted using MCMC method

title: plot MCMC trace plots ‚Äî plotMCMCtrace
code: plotMCMCtrace(   object,   target = c("loglik", "PDF", "CDF", "QF"),   X = NULL,   Y = NULL,   tau = 0.5,   window = NULL )

title: plot MCMC trace plots ‚Äî plotMCMCtrace
text: object object class SPQR. target character indicating statistic/estimate traceplot plotted; "loglik": log-likelihood (default), "PDF": probability density function, "CDF": cumulative density function, "QF": quantile function. X target != "loglik", row vector specifying covariate values estimates computed. Default: NULL. Y target = "PDF" target = "CDF" scalar specifying response value estimates computed. Default: NULL. tau target != "QF", scalar specifying quantile level estimates computed. Default: 0.5. window vector specifying range index MCMC samples traceplot plotted. Default NULL indicating whole chain plotted.

title: plot MCMC trace plots ‚Äî plotMCMCtrace
text: ggplot object.

title: plot MCMC trace plots ‚Äî plotMCMCtrace
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5) Y <- rnorm(n, X, 0.8) control <- list(iter = 200, warmup = 150, thin = 1) fit <- SPQR(X = X, Y = Y, method = "MCMC", control = control,             normalize = TRUE, verbose = FALSE)  ## trace plot for log-likelihood plotMCMCtrace(fit, target = "loglik")  # }

title: plot accumulated local effects (ALE) ‚Äî plotQALE
text: Computes plots quantile ALEs SPQR class object. function plots ALE main effects across tau single covariate using line plots, ALE interaction effects two covariates across tau using contour plots.

title: plot accumulated local effects (ALE) ‚Äî plotQALE
code: plotQALE(object, ...)

title: plot accumulated local effects (ALE) ‚Äî plotQALE
text: object object class "SPQR". ... Arguments passed QALE var.index numeric scalar length-two vector indices covariates ALEs calculated. length(var.index) = 1, function computes main effect X[,var.index]. length(var.index) = 2, function computes interaction effect X[,var.index[1]] X[,var.index[2]]. tau quantiles interest. n.bins maximum number intervals covariate range divided   calculating ALEs. actual number intervals depends number unique values X[,var.index]. length(var.index) = 2, n.bins applied covariates. ci.level credible level computing pointwise credible intervals ALE length(var.index) = 1. default 0 indicating credible intervals computed. getAll TRUE length(var.index) = 1, extracts posterior samples ALE. pred.fun function used instead predict.SPQR() computing predicted quantiles given covariates. can useful user wants compare QALE calculated using SPQR using quantile regression models, maybe using true model simulation study.

title: plot accumulated local effects (ALE) ‚Äî plotQALE
text: ggplot object.

title: plot accumulated local effects (ALE) ‚Äî plotQALE
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- runif(n,0,2) Y <- rnorm(n,X^2,0.3+X/2) control <- list(iter = 200, warmup = 150, thin = 1) fit <- SPQR(X=X, Y=Y, n.knots=12, n.hidden=3, method="MCMC",             control=control, normalize=TRUE) #>  #> Starting NUTS at 2026-02-13 20:41:50.099707 #> Error in globalCallingHandlers(condition = global_progression_handler): should not be called with handlers on the stack  ## compute quantile ALE main effect of X at tau = 0.2,0.5,0.8 plotQALE(fit, var.index=1, tau=c(0.2,0.5,0.8)) #> Error: object 'fit' not found # }

what: plot variable importance comparison by quantile ‚Äî plotQVI
title: plot variable importance comparison by quantile ‚Äî plotQVI
text: Computes quantile ALE-induced variable importance (VI) measure covariate specified var.index, produces ranking plot covariates using bar plot quantile interest.

title: plot variable importance comparison by quantile ‚Äî plotQVI
code: plotQVI(object, var.index = NULL, var.names = NULL, ...)

title: plot variable importance comparison by quantile ‚Äî plotQVI
text: object object class SPQR. var.index vector specifying index covariates VI measures computed. Default NULL indicating covariates considered. var.names names covariates appear bar plots. Default NULL function use generic names generated parse(text=paste0("X[",var.index,"]")). ... Arguments passed QALE tau quantiles interest. n.bins maximum number intervals covariate range divided   calculating ALEs. actual number intervals depends number unique values X[,var.index]. length(var.index) = 2, n.bins applied covariates. ci.level credible level computing pointwise credible intervals ALE length(var.index) = 1. default 0 indicating credible intervals computed. pred.fun function used instead predict.SPQR() computing predicted quantiles given covariates. can useful user wants compare QALE calculated using SPQR using quantile regression models, maybe using true model simulation study.

title: plot variable importance comparison by quantile ‚Äî plotQVI
text: ggplot object.

title: plot variable importance comparison by quantile ‚Äî plotQVI
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- matrix(runif(n*2, 0, 2), nrow = n, ncol = 2) Y <- rnorm(n, X[,1]^2, 0.3+X[,1]/2) control <- list(iter = 200, warmup = 150, thin = 1) fit <- SPQR(X=X, Y=Y, n.knots=12, n.hidden=5, method="MCMC",             control=control, normalize=TRUE, verbose = FALSE)  ## compute quantile VI of at tau = 0.2,0.5,0.8 plotQVI(fit, tau=c(0.2,0.5,0.8))  # }

what: predict method for class SPQR ‚Äî predict.SPQR
title: predict method for class SPQR ‚Äî predict.SPQR
text: Computes predicted values different functions based fitted "SPQR" object.

title: predict method for class SPQR ‚Äî predict.SPQR
code: # S3 method for class 'SPQR' predict(   object,   X,   Y = NULL,   nY = 101,   type = c("QF", "PDF", "CDF"),   tau = seq(0.1, 0.9, 0.1),   ci.level = 0,   getAll = FALSE,   ... )

title: predict method for class SPQR ‚Äî predict.SPQR
text: object object class SPQR. X covariate vector/matrix predictions computed. Y response vector predictions computed. Default NULL indicating equi-distant grid vector [0,1] length nY used. nY integer number indicating length grid Y specified. Default: 101. type function predicted; "PDF": probability density function, "CDF": cumulative distribution function, "QF": quantile function (default). tau grid quantiles quantile function computed. Default: seq(0.1,0.9,0.1). ci.level credible level computing pointwise credible intervals. default 0 indicating credible intervals computed. getAll TRUE, extracts posterior samples prediction. Default: FALSE. ... arguments.

title: predict method for class SPQR ‚Äî predict.SPQR
text: named array containing predicted values.

title: predict method for class SPQR ‚Äî predict.SPQR
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5) Y <- rnorm(n, X, 0.8) control <- list(iter = 200, warmup = 150, thin = 1) fit <- SPQR(X = X, Y = Y, method = "MCMC", control = control,             normalize = TRUE, verbose = FALSE)  ## compute the estimated PDF of Y conditioned on X = 0 pdf <- predict(fit, type = "PDF", X = 0, Y = seq(0, 1, 0.01)) plot(seq(0, 1, 0.01), pdf, xlab = "Y", ylab = "Density")  # }

title: print method for class SPQR ‚Äî print.SPQR
text: equivalent function call print.summary.SPQR(summary.SPQR(object), ...).

title: print method for class SPQR ‚Äî print.SPQR
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5) Y <- rnorm(n, X, 0.8) control <- list(iter = 200, warmup = 150, thin = 1) fit <- SPQR(X = X, Y = Y, method = "MCMC", control = control,             normalize = TRUE, verbose = FALSE) print(fit, showModel = TRUE) #>  #> SPQR fitted using MCMC approach with ARD priorüöÄ #>  #> Model specification: #>     Layers #>    Input Output Activation #>        1     10       tanh #>       10     10    softmax #>  #> MCMC diagnostics: #>   Final acceptance ratio is 0.95 and target is 0.9 #>  #> Expected log pointwise predictive density (elpd) estimates: #>   elpd.LOO = 90.10687,  elpd.WAIC = 89.59815 #>  #> Elapsed time: 0.02 minutes # }

title: summary method for class SPQR ‚Äî summary.SPQR

title: summary method for class SPQR ‚Äî summary.SPQR
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(919) n <- 200 X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5) Y <- rnorm(n, X, 0.8) control <- list(iter = 200, warmup = 150, thin = 1) fit <- SPQR(X = X, Y = Y, method = "MCMC", control = control,             normalize = TRUE, verbose = FALSE)  ## summarize output summary(fit) #>  #> SPQR fitted using MCMC approach with ARD priorüöÄ #>  #> MCMC diagnostics: #>   Final acceptance ratio is 0.95 and target is 0.9 #>  #> Expected log pointwise predictive density (elpd) estimates: #>   elpd.LOO = 90.10687,  elpd.WAIC = 89.59815 #>  #> Elapsed time: 0.02 minutes # }
